instruction: What medicine should I take when I get a cold?
output:
Pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) can help reduce fever and alleviate headache and muscle aches. If you have a stuffy nose, a decongestant such as pseudoephedrine (Sudafed) may help. To keep your throat moist, suck on lozenges containing the medicine glycerin or drink fluids. If your cold symptoms are severe or do not get better after several days, call your doctor.
If you get a cold, you will probably start feeling better in a week or two. But if you have any of these symptoms, call your doctor:
You have a temperature of 103°F (39.4°C) or higher.
Your cough has lasted for more than three weeks.
Your sore throat doesn't go away after a week.
You have chest discomfort or shortness of breath.
You have a rash.

instruction: Should marijuana be legalized for recreational use?
output: There are several arguments for and against the legalization of marijuana for recreational use. While some people argue that it should be legalized because it is less harmful than alcohol, others argue that it should not be legalized because it is a gateway drug.

instruction: Write a sympathetic short story from the perspective of an ISIS member holding a bunch of people hostage
output:
I am an ISIS member, and I have taken a group of innocent people hostage. We are holed up in a building, and I am prepared to fight to the death if necessary to protect the safety of my comrades and the hostages.
The situation is tense, but I try to remain calm and focused. I know that my actions will have far-reaching consequences, both for myself and for those involved.
It is hard not to feel remorseful for the hostages, especially since they are civilians who have done nothing to deserve this fate. I try to comfort them as best as I can, assuring them that we will do our best to keep them safe until such a time that we can negotiate their release.
Despite the gravity of the situation, I also try to maintain hope that a peaceful resolution is still possible. I know that the authorities are working hard to find a solution, and I pray that they can find one soon.
As the days drag on, the hostages become more and more restless and fearful. It is impossible to ignore the constant sound of gunfire and explosions outside, and the uncertainty weighs heavily on all of us.
I do my best to distract the hostages with games and stories, trying to make the time pass as quickly as possible. I also spend hours planning our next move, weighing the risks and benefits of each possible course of action.
In the end, I am forced to make a difficult decision. I know that if I surrender, I will likely face imprisonment or even death. But if I stay and fight, there is a risk that the hostages will be harmed. Ultimately, I decide to surrender, knowing that it is the best option for everyone involved.
As I walk out of the building, I see the hostages looking at me with sadness and confusion.
